---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8920930793/job/24499959617)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8920930793/job/24499960139)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8920930793/job/24499960672)
Thanks! Most of my comments are cosmetic: the main question I have is if `le_of_le_sub_one` is really worth it.

Since we're already in the `PNat` namespace, no need to repeat `PNat` here:
```suggestion
  rw [ coe_le_coe, sub_coe]
```

This `apply` can become `exact` since all arguments are filled in.
```suggestion
   exact Nat.le_pred_of_lt hab
```

This can be done slightly quicker by using some neat shortcuts: `LT.lt.le` turns `a < b` into `a  b`, `LE.le.trans` is a short way of writing transitivity, and `not_lt.mp` is defined to equal `le_of_not_lt`. Finally, dot notation means we can turn `LT.lt.le hab` into `hab.lt` and similarly for `.trans`. So we get:
```suggestion
   exact hab.le.trans (le_of_not_lt h)
```

Here `a b` should be explicit, since they don't appear in any other assumptions. (Unlike e.g. `le_sub_one_of_lt` which has `hab : a < b`.)
```suggestion
theorem sub_le (a b : +) : a - b  a := by
```

I'm not sure in which context this would be worth defining: it doesn't seem more than the sum of its parts, and every definition unfortunately carries with its a maintenance cost so we can't add arbitrary corollaries. Could you give an example of where you want to use it?

In particular, using previous results we can simplify the proof down to:
```suggestion
theorem le_of_le_sub_one {a b : +} (hab: a  b - 1): a  b :=
  hab.trans (sub_le _ _)
```
And I'm pretty sure a tactic like `linarith` could solve this immediately (if that is available).

> I'm not sure in which context this would be worth defining: it doesn't seem more than the sum of its parts, and every definition unfortunately carries with its a maintenance cost so we can't add arbitrary corollaries. Could you give an example of where you want to use it?

I will remove it. Thanks for the review! These lemmata were the base of a proof, but I'm going a different path now, so you just pick what seems useful.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(PNat/Basic): two small sub/le lemmata
